. Polynesia is generally defined as the islands within the Polynesian
  triangle.]]


'Polynesia' (from "poly" many + "nÄsos" island) is a subregion of Oceania, made
up of over 1,000 islands scattered over the central and southern Pacific Ocean.
The indigenous people who inhabit the islands of Polynesia are termed
Polynesians and they share many similar traits including language, culture and
beliefs. Historically, they were experienced sailors and used
stars to navigate during the night.

The term "Polynesia" was first used in 1756 by French writer Charles de Brosses,
and originally applied to all the islands of the Pacific. In 1831, Jules Dumont
d'Urville proposed a restriction on its use during a lecture to the Geographical
Society of Paris.
